questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 1:1-18 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Paul's authority and the false gospel.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'accursed' in verse 8, which is a strong condemnation of false teaching
Pay attention to the phrase 'I am not a man' (v. 13) showing Paul's humility

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) is speaking to, WHAT (the gospel he preached), WHERE (the churches in Galatia), and WHY (to correct the false teaching).
tips: Include Paul's claim that he received the gospel through revelation (v. 11-12)
Note that Paul had been a persecutor of the church (v. 13-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's claim of being set apart before birth (v. 15), the phrase 'the gospel is not of human origin' (v. 12), or the strong condemnation of false gospel (v. 8)?
tips: Paul's statement that he was set apart by God before birth (v. 15) shows a unique relationship with Christ
The phrase 'the gospel is not of human origin' (v. 12) emphasizes the divine nature of the gospel
The word 'accursed' in verse 8 is a powerful warning against false teaching

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia through this passage?
tips: Paul is defending the authenticity of the gospel he preached, which is not from human effort but from Christ
He emphasizes that salvation comes through Christ alone and not through human works or false teachings
This passage is a direct response to the false gospel being promoted in the Galatian churches

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The claim of being set apart before birth? Why the gospel is not of human origin? The phrase 'accursed'?
tips: The phrase 'set apart before birth' (v. 15) refers to God's sovereign choice of Paul even before he was born, a concept that may be difficult to grasp
The term 'gospel' (v. 12) in this context means the good news of Christ, but Paul is emphasizing it is not of human origin (i.e., not created by men)
The word 'accursed' (v. 8) is a strong term that indicates a severe condemnation of those who teach a false gospel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul's gospel is not of human origin but revealed by Christ. What area of your life requires you to trust the gospel of Christ alone this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you are trying to rely on your own efforts to achieve salvation
Think about how the gospel being 'not of human origin' means you don't have to earn it through works
Pray for the strength to reject any false gospel that might be influencing you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that the gospel is not of human origin but revealed by Christ. Ask for courage to reject false teachings.
tips: Thank God for revealing Christ as the source of the gospel
Pray for the strength to stand firm in the true gospel
Ask God to help you recognize and avoid any false gospel that might be leading you astray

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 2:1-20 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Paul's teaching and the false teachers.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'justified by faith' (v.19)
Pay attention to the phrase 'crucified with Christ' (v.19) which is a key metaphor
Listen for the shift in emphasis from law to faith in the closing verses

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul and the churches in Galatia) is involved, WHAT (the gospel message of justification by faith), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to preserve the truth of the gospel against false teachers).
tips: Include Paul's journey to Jerusalem with Barnabas and Titus (v.1-2)
Note the false brothers who tried to force circumcision on Titus (v.3-4)
Describe Paul's declaration that we are justified by faith in Christ, not by works of the law (v.19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's defense of faith (v.19), the contrast with Peter (v.9), or the declaration 'I have been crucified with Christ' (v.19)?
tips: Paul's declaration in v.19: 'We know that a person is not justified by works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ' is foundational
The phrase 'crucified with Christ' (v.19) shows the depth of our union with Christ
The closing statement 'It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me' (v.20) is a powerful reminder of Christ's presence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia about the nature of justification and the gospel?
tips: Paul is defending the truth that we are justified by faith in Christ alone, not by works of the law
This is critical to prevent the Galatian churches from being enslaved to the law
The gospel message is that we are dead to the law and alive to Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'justified by faith' (v.19), the meaning of 'crucified with Christ' (v.19), or the historical context of circumcision as a requirement?
tips: 'Justified by faith' means being declared righteous by God through trust in Christ, not by human effort
Being 'crucified with Christ' means we have died to the old self and are now united to Christ in his death and resurrection

Circumcision was a sign of the covenant with Israel; false teachers wanted to add it to Gentiles to make them part of the covenant, but Paul argues this is unnecessary because we are justified by fait

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live by the freedom in Christ that Paul describes this week? Focus on one area where you might be trying to earn God's approval.
tips: Consider a habit or behavior that you think makes you 'justified' (like religious rituals)
Practice the freedom to live by faith alone, not by trying to follow the law
Remember that you are 'crucified with Christ'â€”so your life should reflect that you are dead to the law and alive to Christ

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about being justified by faith and not by works, and about living by the presence of Christ in you.
tips: Thank God that you are justified by faith in Christ, not by works
Ask for the courage to live without the burden of trying to earn God's favor
Pray that Christ's life within you will guide your actions and decisions

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 3:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the law and the promise.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'by hearing with faith' (v.5, v.10, v.14)
Pay attention to the phrase 'sons of Abraham' (v.7, v.15, v.29)
The phrase 'Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law' (v.13) is a key declaration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the Galatian churches), WHAT (the role of law vs. faith in salvation), WHERE (the church in Galatia), and WHY (to correct the misunderstanding of salvation by works).
tips: Abraham's faith as the basis for blessing (v.6, v.15)
The curse of the law for those who try to be justified by works (v.13)
The unity of all in Christ (v.28)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the promise to Abraham (v.16), Christ becoming a curse (v.13), or the unity in Christ (v.28)?
tips: The promise 'In you shall all the nations be blessed' (v.16) is a profound statement of God's global plan
Christ becoming a curse (v.13) shows the depth of the cross and the cost of redemption
The unity statement: 'There is neither Jew nor Greek...' (v.28) is a radical declaration of inclusion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia through this passage?
tips: Paul is correcting the Galatians who were being tempted to add the law to their salvation (v.1-5)
The main point is that salvation comes by faith in Christ, not by the law (v.1-14)
This passage shows that the law was a temporary guardian until Christ came (v.24-25)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of the law, the concept of being a curse, or the promise to Abraham?
tips: The law does not annul a covenant (v.12) because it was given after the covenant with Abraham (v.15) - the law was a temporary measure to guide until Christ
Christ becoming a curse (v.13) refers to the curse of the law that believers would have to bear without Christ
The phrase 'sons of Abraham' (v.29) means those who have faith are part of Abraham's spiritual lineage, not by physical descent

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the idea that we are sons of Abraham by faith (v.29) challenge you to live differently this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are trying to be 'justified by works' (v.10) instead of by faith
Pray for the courage to live as a child of Abraham (v.29) in a world that separates people by ethnicity and status
This week, share one thing you have been holding back from God because of your fear of failure

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He has made us sons of Abraham by faith. Ask for the courage to live as one in Christ.
tips: Thank God for the promise that all nations are blessed through Abraham
Pray for unity in Christ among diverse groups (Jew, Greek, slave, free)
Ask God to help you see the curse of the law and the freedom in Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 4:1-7 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the two covenants and the phrase 'Abba! Father!' in verse 6.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'when we were children' (v.1) and 'now' (v.4,5,7)
Pay attention to the contrast between Hagar (v.21) and Sarah (v.23) as the two covenants

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the church in Galatia), WHAT (the contrast between being under law and adopted as sons), WHERE (the spiritual realm), and WHY (to avoid being enslaved to the old covenant).
tips: Include the three key elements: the old covenant (Hagar), the new covenant (Sarah), and the Spirit's role (v.6)
Note that the church was previously enslaved to the 'elementary principles of the world' (v.1) but now are sons (v.5,6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast of the two covenants (v.21-23), the cry 'Abba! Father!' (v.6), or the declaration of being heirs (v.7).
tips: The phrase 'Abba! Father!' (v.6) shows the intimate relationship with God that the Spirit enables
The comparison of Hagar (the old covenant) to Mount Sinai and the new covenant to the Jerusalem above (v.24) is a powerful image
The statement 'you are sons' (v.7) is the culmination of the passage, showing the new identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia through this passage about their identity in Christ?
tips: Paul is warning against returning to the old covenant (law) and emphasizing that they are already sons of God through Christ
The main point is that through Christ, believers are adopted as sons and heirs, not bound by the old covenant
This passage addresses the fear that the Galatians might revert to the 'elementary principles' (v.1) because they had been saved by grace

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between the two covenants, the meaning of 'elementary principles', or the role of the Spirit?
tips: The term 'elementary principles' (v.1) refers to the basic teachings of the law that were being followed by the Galatians, but it's not the same as the full law
The concept of being 'heirs' (v.7) is a promise of eternal blessing, but the passage emphasizes that this inheritance is by faith in Christ, not by works
The 'two women' (Hagar and Sarah) are allegorical for the old and new covenants, which might be confusing without context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage this week? Consider: What area of your life needs to be 'free' from the old covenant (law) and embrace your identity as a son of God?
tips: Identify one area where you might be acting like a slave (e.g., legalistic practices) and ask how the Spirit is helping you to cry 'Abba! Father!'
Pray for the courage to let go of the old covenant (Hagar) and embrace the new covenant (Sarah) in your life
Practice the freedom of being an heir by making a decision that aligns with Christ's love, not the law

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about being adopted as sons and heirs through Christ. Ask for the Spirit to help you cry 'Abba! Father!' in your daily life.
tips: Thank God for the gift of adoption as sons through Christ
Pray for the strength to live without being enslaved to the old covenant
Ask for the Spirit to help you experience the freedom of being an heir (v.7)

chapters.chapterTitle: Freedom in Christ and the Fruit of the Spirit

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 5:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the law and the Spirit.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'freedom' (v.1) and 'walk by the Spirit' (v.16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the churches in Galatia) is being encouraged, WHAT (to walk by the Spirit and not be enslaved to the law), WHERE (in the context of the church), and WHY (to maintain freedom in Christ).
tips: Include the key phrase: 'the whole law is fulfilled in one word: love your neighbor as yourself' (v.14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the list of 'fruit of the spirit' (v.22-23), the phrase 'crucified the flesh' (v.24), or the contrast between 'works of the flesh' and 'fruit of the spirit' (v.19-23).
tips: The list of nine fruits (v.22-23) is a powerful reminder of what character growth looks like
The phrase 'crucified the flesh' (v.24) is a strong image of the believer's new identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia through this passage?
tips: Paul's goal was to prevent the Galatian churches from reverting to legalism and to encourage them to live by the Spirit
This passage emphasizes that true freedom in Christ leads to a life of love and spiritual maturity

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between the law and the Spirit, the meaning of 'crucified the flesh', and the list of 'works of the flesh'.
tips: The phrase 'works of the flesh' (v.19-21) refers to sinful behaviors that are characteristic of those who are not in Christ, not the law itself
The concept of being 'crucified with the flesh' (v.24) means that the old self (with sinful desires) is dead, but the new self (the Spirit) is alive

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the fruit of the spirit in your daily life this week? Focus on one fruit (e.g., love, patience) and take a step.
tips: Choose one fruit of the spirit (e.g., 'kindness') and think of a situation where you can show it today
Remember that the fruit of the spirit grows through the Spirit's work, so ask God for help to produce it

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for freedom in Christ and ask for the fruit of the spirit to grow in your life.
tips: Thank God for setting you free from the law and for the gift of the Spirit
Pray for courage to live by the Spirit and not to be enslaved to the flesh

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Galatians 6:1-10 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'bear one another's burdens', 'sow to the Spirit', and 'new creation'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'bear one another's burdens' (v.2) and the contrast with 'sow to the Spirit' (v.7-8)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Paul's warning about self-deception (v.3) and the call for mutual support (v.2)
Note the phrase 'new creation' (v.15) as a key theological shift

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the believers in Galatia), WHAT (bearing burdens and restoring others), WHERE (the church community), and WHY (to fulfill the law of Christ).
tips: Include the context of the Galatian churches being tempted by Judaizers (v.3)
Note the restoration process for those who fall into sin (v.1)
Describe the mutual burden-sharing as the way to fulfill the law of Christ (v.2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'bear one another's burdens' (v.2), 'sow to the Spirit' (v.7-8), or 'new creation' (v.15)?
tips: 'Bear one another's burdens' in v.2 shows active, practical love that goes beyond mere words
The promise in v.8 that 'sow to the Spirit will reap eternal life' is a powerful reminder of God's faithfulness
The concept of 'new creation' (v.15) as a radical identity shift from old works to Christ is transformative

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the churches in Galatia about living as believers in Christ?
tips: Paul emphasizes that true faith is lived out through mutual support and burden-sharing, not through external rituals
The law of Christ (v.2) is fulfilled by community, not by rules of the Law of Moses
The new creation (v.15) means that our identity is in Christ, not in circumcision or works

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'bear one another's burdens', the self-deception warning, or the concept of 'new creation'?
tips: 'Bear one another's burdens' requires active, compassionate engagement with others' struggles, which can be difficult in a culture of individualism
Paul's warning about self-deception (v.3) addresses the danger of false confidence in one's own righteousness
'New creation' (v.15) refers to a complete transformation in identity, not just a spiritual state, which can be hard to grasp

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you bear one another's burdens this week? Identify a burden someone in your life is carrying and offer practical help.
tips: Consider an area where you might be holding back from helping others (e.g., fear of judgment)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the gift of bearing burdens and ask for strength to live in community.
tips: Thank God for the community of believers who share burdens with you
Pray for the courage to bear others' burdens without becoming burdened yourself
Ask God to help you see the new creation in others and in yourself
